_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Energy Transfer Pike Compressor Station located in Parker, Pennsylvania is a natural gas compressor

station. This facility receives and processes liquid petroleum gases (LPGs) and delivers them to the

gathering pipeline.



Two requirements of this section specifically apply to operations at the Pike Compressor Station:



1. Purpose and General Duty Clause - The essence of the general duty clause is that an

owner/operator that stores and uses hazardous chemicals in any quantity has a fundamental

obligation to ensure a safe operation and to have plans in place in the event of an accident to

appropriately manage the situation. Energy Transfer is committed to ensuring the safe operation of

the Pike Compressor Station, as well as all of its other operations, to ensure a safe workplace for our

employees and a safe location for our neighbors in the community. Energy Transfer, therefore, has

procedures in place to prevent accidents and is committed to emergency preparedness both for our

facility and community-wide by coordinating with the local Fire Department and the Beaver County

Emergency Services.



2. Risk Management Plan - The primary function of the Pike Compressor Station is to function as a

compression station for LPGs. Due to the flammable effects associated with LPGs, it is necessary

to observe certain safety precautions to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the threat

to employee health, and to minimize the threat and impact to nearby members of the community.



Energy Transfer's Pike Compressor Station is strongly committed to employee, public, and environmental

safety and health. Safety at the facility depends on the manner in which LPG is handled as well as

the various safety devices incorporated into the design of the process. Furthermore, comprehensive

training is provided to employees and contractors which reinforces the safety policies and

procedures of the facility. Programs have been established to help prevent any ac

cidental releases

and to train personnel for emergency response in the event of a release.



For planning purposes, Energy Transfer has considered the impact of worst case and alternative

release scenarios. The probability of the worst case catastrophic event evaluated in this report is

extremely remote. The worst case scenario is far less probable than natural catastrophes that could 

produce much more severe and extensive damage and injury. A consideration of the release scenarios 

has been incorporated into Energy Transfer's notification and emergency response planning. Energy 

Transfer also considered the impact of a more likely loss of containment.



Energy Transfer has not had any covered process incidents in the past five years. Energy Transfer

has implemented safety precautions and procedures designed to prevent and mitigate catastrophic 

releases. Energy Transfer has active operating, maintenance, training and inspection procedures.

Energy Transfer provides annual emergency response training to its employees. Energy Transfer's 

management is committed to the following:

- Preventing accidents;

- Continuing to proactively seek out improvements to process safety;

- Training employees in correct response procedures in the event of an accident;

- Participating in community emergency preparedness;

- Addressing any citizen concerns by fully explaining potential hazards associated with operations

and all steps being taken to prevent and mitigate accidents; and

- Being a good corporate citizen in Beaver County.



With these objectives in mind, the Risk Management Plan has been developed to provide

information about our management of the risks associated with this Station. Most important, Energy

Transfer stresses our commitment to ensuring a safe operation for our employees, our visitors, and

our community.
